com.reactivecascade.reactive

Class ReactiveValue<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.reactivecascade.util.Origin
      • com.reactivecascade.reactive.Subscription<T,T>
        • com.reactivecascade.reactive.ReactiveValue<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IAsyncOrigin, IGettable<T>, INamed, IReactiveSource<T>, IReactiveTarget<T>, IReactiveValue<T>, ISafeGettable<T>, ISettable<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    PersistentValue, ReactiveInteger, ReactiveLong, ReactiveString

    public class ReactiveValue<T>
extends Subscription<T,T>
implements IReactiveValue<T>
    Thread-safe reactive display of a variable getValue. Add one or more IActionOne actions to update the display when the variable fires. Usually these can be added as Lambda expressions referencing the UI element you would like to track the variable's getValue in an eventually-consistent manner.

    Note the all get()-style actions will return the latest getValue. Therefore asynchronous calls may not result in all values

    Bindings are thread safe. All reactiveTargets will refire concurrently if the IThreadType allows, but individual reactiveTargets will never be called concurrently or out-of-sequence. Multiple changes to the bound getValue within a short time relative to the current speed of the IThreadType may coalesce into a single headFunctionalChainLink refire of only the most recent getValue. Bound functions must be idempotent. Repeat firing of the same getValue is filter under most but not all circumstances. This possibility is related to the use of WeakReference of the previously fired getValue of each headFunctionalChainLink to minimize memory load.

    • Method Detail

      • fire

        @CallSuper
public void fire()
        Run all reactive functional chains bound to this ReactiveValue.

        Normally you do not need to call this, it is called for you. Instead, call set(Object) to assert a new from.

        You can also link this to receive multiple reactive updates as a down-chain IReactiveSource.subscribe(IActionOne) to receive and store reactive values.

        You can also link into a active chain to receive individually constructed and fired updates using 

                 myAltFuture.subscribe(from -> myAtomicValue.set(from))

        Both of these methods will automatically call fire() for you.

        You may want to fire() manually on app startup after all your initial reactive chains are constructed. This will heat up the reactive chain to initial state by flushing current values through the system.

        All methods and receivers within a reactive chain are supposed to be idempotent to multiple firing events. This does not however mean the calls are free or give a good user experience and from as in the case of requesting data multiple times from a server. You have been warned.

      • compareAndSet

        @CallSuper
public boolean compareAndSet(@Nullable
                                        T expected,
                                        @Nullable
                                        T update)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveValue
        Replace the current valueAR with an update, but only if the valueAR is the expected valueAR.

        This is a high performance concurrent atomic compare-split-swap. For more information, see AtomicReference.compareAndSet(Object, Object)

        Specified by:
        compareAndSet in interface IReactiveValue<T>
        Parameters:
        expected - - Must be of the same type as update and must be the current from or the state will not change.
        update - - The asserted new from.
        Returns:
        true of the expected from was the current from and the change of state completed successfully
